body: :+1:  For this. :)

:+1: :heart:
another event `page-favicon-set` would be useful too.

Much of this can be done in theory using a preload script, but those are known to be unruly. So far I have had little success using them reliably.

(This message written from my in-development atom-shell web-browser, which is a case-in-point for this issue)
It wil be even better if we can access the `webContents` of the `webview` tag - we can get all those events for free. We can even do things like event.preventDefault.

@yyjhao, A combination of a preload script and ipc messaging can make accessing the document just as easy, though you generally have to wait for the DOMContentLoaded event before you can start using it.
@yyjhao Hmm, good question, I can't think of a good way to do that.
Yeah things like that may not be necessary for all applications. But right now I wanna add some loading animations before the page is fully loaded to an online web app and it can't be done :(
I think this is a bit wonky - since ipc is asynchronous, `stop()` may be called after the navigation.

@yyjhao I've tested it on several remote sites and they all work perfectly, so far (granted I have incredibly slow internet speed :P). However, on local sites it might be an issue.

EDIT: On local sites it can occasionally cause the embedded page to appear to have locked up. This is because the page gets unloaded, but not un-rendered before the webview stops.
Like I said, this is too hacky to be used in actual apps. A webContents API will be much neater.
@yyjhao Yes, indeed.
I think we have all necessary events now.

Hi @zcbenz ,
did I missed something? Is there new events available but not yet documented?
Oops, I didn't notice this issue is about webview's events.
OK, thank you @zcbenz :)
+1 Better control over webview would allow new class of applications (similar to http://fluidapp.com for example).
+1, would like to have these
+1, I also want to catch `will-navigate` event in `<webview>` to open the link with external browser.
+1, it could be a possible way to forbid file downloads (well, it may depend on which information we can grab from the link target before preventing the event).
+1, catch will-navigate event in <webview> is useful.
+1 for the same reason as @rhysd
+1, how much work will this take?
Now that `chrome.webRequest.*` APIs have now been supported, could we close this?
@steelbrain is there a way to catch only the "root" request (the one which change the url) with `webRequest API`?

@steelbrain in any case, navigation events concerns NAVIGATION and not request, which is different, especially with HTML5 javascript API:
- url can be set without making any request
- history can be changed without making any request
- anchor is part of the navigation, webRequest does not have access to it

@felicienfrancois There **could** be a way of catching only the root request but I haven't dug deep into the API docs yet to know. Anyways, the points that you made are very valid, I agree that this issue is different than that. Thanks for the clarification!
@zcbenz as a workaround would it be possible to get the `webContents` of a webview in the main process?
+1 for event.preventDefault() on will-navigate

> @zcbenz as a workaround would it be possible to get the webContents of a webview in the main process?

There's a getter that returns the associated webContents of a webview tag, and that webContents will also emit a will-navigate event, but calling `preventDefault` on that event will not prevent anything either.

From what I can gather in this thread, implementing that would be problematic because those events are dispatched asynchronously? And dispatching them synchronously would incur a performance penalty?

It appears the documentation is incorrect on this, from the [will-navigate](http://electron.atom.io/docs/api/web-contents/#event-will-navigate) docs it says:

> Calling event.preventDefault() will prevent the navigation.

This appears to not be the case as per the above comment and my tests, can somebody please update the docs, or if you prefer point me in the right direction to update the docs and I will issue a PR.

preventDefault() to prevent navigation on will-navigate would definitely be useful.

As a possible workaround, is there a way to intercept and cancel navigation events from within the webview page (since it's in the same process)?

@kasrak there is no reliable workaround.
Depending on your case, you can:
- use [beforeunload](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onbeforeunload) event (but it may not catch all navigation and it can be overrided by the web page).
- wrap `window.location` and `window.history` with a watcher (but you won't be able to catch navigation with links or `webview.loadUrl`)

I'm wondering what prevents this kind of functionality to be built,
seems like it's a wide-spread problem and this issue is more than a year old.

@tmpfs the [webview documentation](http://electron.atom.io/docs/api/web-view-tag/#event-will-navigate) is right.
You're pointing to the webContents doc. If you think it is wrong you can [edit this file](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/web-contents.md) and make a PR

The webContents documentation is wrong in the sense that:
- You can get a webContents that 'corresponds to' a webview
- preventDefault will _NOT_ work there.

It's mentioned in the webview doc, but should also be mentioned in the webContents doc ("If you've obtained the webContents from a webview then the following caveats apply: ") - or even better, preventDefault could be implemented in webview's will-navigate :)
[![Bountysource](https://api.bountysource.com/badge/issue?issue_id=10652270)](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/10652270-webview-navigation-events)

How do I prevent any and all navigation (except my own page). Perhaps it should simply be an option in the loadURL() method. Because that is the main reason people use the event for (wanting to open it in a real browser window).
@fdn that doesn't work.
I'm thinking if I pass everything through in-node proxy, and will killing requests on the proxy level, need to play with it to see how it can handle https requests.
@alexindigo good enough?

@xywz @mkinawy Thank you for the hacks, it's very nice that you can come up with cleaver ways to game the game, but it's fragile until it's part of public native API.

@zcbenz @kevinsawicki is there any light in the end of the tunnel for this? Thank you.
@kevinsawicki very thanks!

I'm going to close this issue out since Electron now has the events mentioned and the `will-navigate` issue has been discussed and documented how it should be done and why.

Please open new issues for any additional missing events or bugs with `will-navigate`.
